Introduction

De Quervain tendinopathy is an overuse syndrome affecting the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons in the first extensor compartment of the wrist.  It typically presents with pain and tenderness along the radial (lateral) aspect of the wrist that worsens with thumb or wrist movement.

Pathogenesis



De Quervain tendinopathy is a stenosing tenosynovitis involving the APL and EPB tendons, typically where they pass beneath the extensor retinaculum within the first dorsal compartment of the wrist (

De Quervain tendinopathy
).



The condition is thought to result from repetitive or excessive use of the wrist and thumb (eg, frequent lifting of infants).  This mechanical overuse places stress on the APL and EPB tendons, leading to thickening of the synovial tendon sheath and fibrosis of the surrounding fibro-osseous tunnel.  As the tunnel narrows, the tendons become entrapped, increasing friction during movement (eg, thumb extension and abduction).



Over time, this process results in tendinous myxoid degeneration, characterized by breakdown and disorganization of collagen fibers, consistent with tendinosis.  De Quervain tendinopathy is considered a degenerative and fibrotic process, rather than a true inflammatory condition.

Risk factors



  • Repetitive thumb or wrist movements (eg, lifting, texting, gardening).
  • Occupational or recreational overuse (eg, manual labor, racket sports).
  • Age 30â€“50.
  • Female sex (10:1 female-to-male ratio), particularly associated with pregnancy and the postpartum period.

Clinical presentation



  • Pain and tenderness at the radial styloid (lateral, thumb side of the wrist).
  • Pain that worsens with thumb or wrist movements (especially thumb flexion with ulnar deviation of the wrist), gripping, pinching, and lifting and holding objects (especially when the wrist is ulnar-deviated).
  • Swelling or palpable thickening over the radial styloid.
  • Decreased grip strength or thumb range of motion in severe cases.

Differential diagnosis



  • Scaphoid fracture:  These fractures often occur during forceful hyperextension of the wrist (eg, fall on an outstretched hand).  Although patients have lateral wrist pain, the tenderness is typically localized over the anatomic snuffbox (
    figure 2
    ), and patient history includes preceding trauma rather than overuse.
  • Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint:  Osteoarthritis at the base of the thumb causes pain that may worsen with passive thumb flexion.  Symptoms are usually chronic, bilateral, and associated with stiffness, swelling, and periarticular bony hypertrophy.
  • Wartenberg syndrome:  Compression of the superficial radial nerve can cause lateral hand and wrist pain, but the pain is typically vague (not sharp) and associated with numbness and/or paresthesia.  Patients often have a history of mechanical wrist compression (eg, heavy wristwatch, handcuffs).
  • Crystal-induced arthropathy (eg, gout, pseudogout):  These joint disorders occasionally affect the wrist and thumb joints.  However, patients typically have acute pain associated with erythema, warmth, and/or swelling of the joint.

Diagnosis



De Quervain tendinopathy is a clinical diagnosis suggested by atraumatic pain and tenderness at the radial styloid and lateral wrist that is aggravated by a provocative maneuver.  In the Finkelstein test, the patient makes a fist with the thumb tucked inside the fingers and the examiner ulnar-deviates the wrist (

image 1
).  The test is positive for de Quervain tendinopathy if it reproduces pain over the radial styloid.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies



Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies are typically not required for isolated de Quervain tendinopathy.  However, if there is consent for another etiology, inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein, rheumatoid factor) may be considered.  Imaging may be used in select cases and often includes ultrasonography and radiography.  Ultrasonography may show thickening of the tendon sheath and extensor retinaculum and excess fluid within the tendon sheath.  Radiography may help exclude first carpometacarpal arthritis and other bony abnormalities.

Management



Initial management focuses on symptom relief.  Conservative measures are usually sufficient because de Quervain tendinopathy often resolves spontaneously over time (<1 year).  Treatment options typically include activity modification (eg, avoid repetitive wrist/thumb movements, modify ergonomic factors), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and a thumb spica splint, which immobilizes the thumb (

figure 3
).



Patients with severe or persistent symptoms can benefit from a corticosteroid injection, administered directly into the tendon sheath.  The injection is often effective, but patients may require a second injection if symptoms recur.  Refractory cases (ongoing symptoms despite conservative treatment and corticosteroids) may benefit from surgical release of the first dorsal compartment.

Prognosis



Most patients recover fully with nonoperative treatment; however, early treatment leads to faster resolution.  In addition, surgical outcomes are typically excellent in persistent cases.

Prevention



Prevention strategies include ergonomic adjustments at workstations or in repetitive activities, proper lifting techniques, and early intervention after the development of symptoms.

Summary



De Quervain tendinopathy (
